Award.AwardTitle: An Online System for the Collection of Textbook Adoption Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Textbooks are an important influence on teachers' instruction and students' learning. While textbooks are nearly ubiquitous in U.S. classrooms, little data is kept on which schools and districts adopt which textbooks, and to what effect. The lack of systematic textbook adoption data is especially troubling given that districts and schools are making important decisions about curriculum materials in light of new college and career readiness standards. This project, funded as part of an effort to improve the measurement of indicators of successful K-12 education, will gather and make publicly available the largest-ever database of mathematics and science textbook adoption data and analyze the impact of textbooks on student achievement in the five largest U.S. states. The goal of the work is to create an online system that could be sustained inexpensively and used to maintain and make publicly available longitudinal data on textbook adoptions moving forward.

The work plan involves four phases. Phase 1 will build a web-based data collection tool and assemble a list of school district contacts for the target states. Phase 2 will gather textbook adoption data in mathematics and science from the districts through phone and email contacts. Phase 3 will analyze textbook adoption patterns and effects. Phase 4 will update the adoption data in the second year and build plans to sustain and expand the tool. The proposed adoption data could have several transformative uses. Researchers could use the data to study patterns in adoption and conduct 'epidemiological studies' of curriculum effectiveness. District personnel could use the data to, to identify other districts adopting their same curricular materials for purposes of collaboration and instructional improvement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purposes of this award were to 1) develop a system to reliably capture data on schools' and districts' textbook adoption patterns in the five most populous U.S. states (CA, TX, IL, FL, NY) and 2) use those data to determine the impact of textbooks on student achievement.

With respect to the first purpose, the project was partially successful--while school districts were reluctant to respond to surveys about their textbook adoptions, we were able to obtain the data in other ways. In particular, we were able to obtain textbook adoption data for all schools in California through their School Accountability Report Cards, in Texas through their state department of education's purchasing records, and in the other three states by sending Freedom of Information requests to all school districts. We learned a considerable amount about how to ask for, collect, and clean these data that could inform future efforts to understand school and district textbook adoptions. We have leveraged the NSF funds to obtain two subsequent grants from private foundations to continue the data collection in California (which is quite time- and labor-intensive). We now have textbook adoption datasets that we are willing to share with interested researchers for the purpose of studying patterns in textbook adoptions and effects.

With respect to the second purpose, the project was successful in elementary mathematics in California, and we are working to see if the data will allow us to estimate textbook effects in other states, subjects, and grades. In California elementary mathematics, we have analyzed textbook adoption data and effects from the 2008 adoption cycle and determined that one book--Houghton Mifflin California Math--out performed the other three most popular books in terms of student achievement effects in grades 3-5. Those effects were large enough to move students from approximately the 50th to the 59th percentile of student achievement (more or less depending on grade and year). That paper was the first to study textbook impacts over three grades and across four years, and it demonstrates the power of having population textbook adoption data. The work was published in AERA Open and in a policy brief through Brookings. 

While the grant period is now ending, we are continuing to use the data and our experiences to answer several questions related to textbook adoptions and effects. One paper currently under advanced review questions the theory and purpose of California's textbook data collection efforts. Another paper uses the Texas data to estimate the impact of English language development materials on ELL students' achievement in Texas (though English was not a focus of this grant, the data we collected through the state have allowed us to answer this question). And a third pairs textbook adoption data with detailed interviews of school district leaders to understand the variation in school districts' textbook adoption practices, pointing the way toward interventions that might work to get better materials in teachers' hands. In addition, we are working on textbook impact analyses 1) in science, 2) in middle school mathematics, and 3) in Texas, where the data will allow such investigations. 

In terms of academic merit, the project has demonstrated new techniques for gathering and analyzing textbook adoption data and drawn further attention to the policy issue of curriculum materials. We have published one journal article and one policy brief, and we currently have three more articles under review and two that are being written for submission. We expect to publish 5-6 journal articles about this work in total. We presented five times at academic conferences. And we also, as mentioned above, have leveraged the funds to obtain two additional grants on this topic--it has catalyzed an entire research agenda around curriculum materials that we are continuing to pursue.

In terms of broader impact, the work was also disseminated through blog posts and policy briefs, as well as through presentations to nonacademic audiences. These efforts have resulted in wide reach and have contributed to the growing research interest in curriculum materials (evidenced, for example, by a new funding stream from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation). The work has been presented in eight different invited sessions and has been covered by National Public Radio, Education Week, and several online education publications. This has led to conversations with three different state departments of education that are considering tracking textbook adoptions so they can study trends and effects, following our method.

In short, the funds have been highly productive and have helped us understand a great deal about textbook adoptions and effects in U.S. schools. While the original goal of creating an easy-to-use reporting tool was not achieved, the other achievements of the project have been impressive.
